{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The introduction of the '''Bahá'í Faith in Vietnam''' first occurred in the 1920s, not long after [[French Indochina]] was mentioned by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] as a potential destination for Bahá'í teachers.{{cite book|author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0877432333 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-7.html.iso8859-1#gr10 | pages = 40–42 |origyear = 1916–17}} After a number of brief visits from travelling teachers throughout the first half of the 20th century, the first Bahá'i group in Vietnam was established in [[Saigon]] in 1954, with the arrival of Shirin Fozdar, a Bahá'í teacher from India. The 1950s and 1960s were marked by periods of rapid growth, mainly in [[South Vietnam]]; despite the [[Vietnam War|ongoing war]] affecting the country, the Bahá'í population surged to around 200,000 adherents by 1975. After the end of the war, Vietnam was reunified under a communist government, who proscribed the practice of the religion from 1975 to 1992, leading to a sharp drop in community numbers. Relations with the government gradually improved, however, and in 2007 the Bahá'í Faith was officially registered, followed by its full legal recognition a year later.{{cite web| title = Small Baha'i And Muslim Communities Grow in Hanoi | publisher=Embassy of the United States of America in Vietnam | format=Diplomatic cable | date=12 September 2007| url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=07HANOI1636 | accessdate=2012-09-25}}{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90159.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report — Vietnam | date = 14 September 2007 | accessdate = 2008-02-23 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}} As of 2012, it was reported that the Bahá'í community comprised about 8,000 followers.{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/religiousfreedom/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=208280#wrapper | title = International Religious Freedom Report—Vietnam | year = 2012 | accessdate = 2013-07-12 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}} ==French Indochina (pre-1954)== ===‘Abdu'l-Bahá's ''Tablets of the Divine Plan''=== The earliest association of Vietnam with the Bahá'í Faith was a brief mention of French Indochina—of which the country was then a part—as a destination for Bahá'í teachers in [[‘Abdu'l-Bahá]]'s ''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]''. The specific tablet in question was written on 11 April 1916, but was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919, after the end of World War I and the Spanish flu. These tablets were translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on 4 April 1919, and published in [[Star of the West]] magazine on 12 December 1919.{{cite book| last = Abbas | first = 'Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url = http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}
"The moment this divine Message is carried forward by the American believers from the shores of America and is propagated through the continents of Europe, of Asia, of Africa and of Australasia, and as far as the islands of the Pacific, this community will find itself securely established upon the throne of an everlasting dominion..., if some teachers go to other islands and other parts, such as the continent of Australia, New Zealand, Tasmania, also to Japan, Asiatic Russia, Korea, French Indochina, Siam, Straits Settlements, India, Ceylon and Afghanistan, most great results will be forthcoming."
‘Abdu’l-Bahá had at one time seriously considered a voyage to India and Indochina, as reported by [[Shoghi Effendi]] in 1919,{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum |year = 1969 |title = The Priceless Pearl |page = 31 | edition = Hardcover |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust: 2000 |location = London, UK |isbn = 978-1-870989-91-6 }} although whether such a voyage would have included the territory that would become known as Vietnam is not known. ===Early contact=== The first Bahá'í to visit Vietnam is likely to have been {{Interlanguage link multi|Hippolyte Dreyfus-Barney|fr}}, one of the first Bahá'ís of France, who undertook a number of travels around the globe at the request of 'Abdu'l-Bahá.{{cite book|title=The Bahá'í World|volume=16|year=1978|publisher=Bahá'í World Centre|location=Haifa|author=The Universal House of Justice|isbn=0853980756|pages=536–537}} After an initial planned visit was aborted in 1914 due to the outbreak of [[World War I]], Dreyfus-Barney arrived in what was then [[French Indochina]] in 1920, visiting Saigon and Hanoi.{{cite web | title = Hippolyte Dreyfus, apôtre d'Abdu'l-Bahá |trans-title=Hippolyte Dreyfus, Disciple of 'Abdu'l-Bahá | url= http://www.bahai-biblio.org/centre-doc/ouvrage/dreyfus/dreyfus_06.htm | date=September 2000 | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of France | accessdate = 2012-09-24 }} Four years later in May 1924, prominent Bahá'í travelling teacher [[Martha Root]] paid a week-long visit to Saigon. During her stay, she promoted the message and principles of the religion to a number of newspapers, making friends with one Madame Boeuf, editor of an English section in "L'Information de l'Extrême Orient". Boeuf was sympathetic to the principles of the Bahá'í religion, and published a number of favorable French-language articles. Several other newspapers also printed articles describing Bahá'í principles, in French, Chinese and Vietnamese. A public lecture was arranged with the help of the Governor, who, when approached, "himself telephoned the President of the largest school" to communicate his approval. Besides these initiatives, Root made calls to nineteen schools, societies and individuals in Saigon.{{cite book|title=Martha Root: Lioness at the threshold|author=M. R. Garis|publisher=Baha'i Publishing Trust|year=1983|isbn=0877431841}}{{cite journal |last=Root |first=Martha |title=A Trip to Indo-China on a Cargo Boat |journal=Star of the West |volume=15 |issue=2 |date=May 1924 |page=40}} In 1951, the [[Spiritual Assembly|National Spiritual Assembly]] of the Bahá'ís of India, Pakistan and Burma adopted the goal of sending [[Pioneering (Baha'i)|pioneers]] to a number of cities throughout Africa and Southeast Asia, including Saigon, in response to the summons of Shoghi Effendi, then head of the Bahá'í Faith.{{cite journal| title = Bahá'í News|date=October 1951 | page=9 | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | issn=0195-9212}} In a letter to an individual in September of that year, Shoghi Effendi reported that there were Bahá’ís in Indochina at that time,{{cite web | title = Japan Will Turn Ablaze! | url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/c/JWTA/jwta-150.html| year=1992 | publisher = Bahá’í Publishing Trust of Japan | accessdate = 2012-09-24 }} although their settlement seems to have been short-lived; a March 1952 report stated that Indochina remained unopened to the Baha'i Faith.{{cite journal| title = Bahá'í Newsletter|date=March 1952 | number=58 | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of India, Pakistan and Burma }} ==South Vietnam (1954–1975)== Following nearly a [[First Indochina War|decade of war]] between colonial France and the communist [[Viet Minh]], which ended in a decisive French defeat at the [[Battle of Dien Bien Phu]], both sides met at the [[Geneva Conference (1954)|Geneva Conference]] on July 21, 1954. A provisional division of Vietnam was made at the [[Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone|17th parallel]], creating the [[North Vietnam|Democratic Republic of Vietnam]] in the north and the [[South Vietnam|State of Vietnam]] (later the [[South Vietnam|Republic of Vietnam]]) in the south.Nash, Gary B., Julie Roy Jeffrey, John R. Howe, Peter J. Frederick, Allen F. Davis, Allan M. Winkler, Charlene Mires, and Carla Gardina Pestana. The American People, Concise Edition Creating a Nation and a Society, Combined Volume (6th Edition). New York: Longman, 2007. Much of the development of the Bahá'í Faith during the following period took place in South Vietnam; the first Bahá'í groups in the north would not be established until 1992, long after the country's reunification. ===Establishment and early growth (1954–1963)=== In February 1954, Shirin Fozdar, a Bahá'í from India who had been a member of the National Spiritual Assembly there, went to Saigon to establish the religion in Indochina.{{cite journal | url = http://www.religiousunity.org/BahArt/Shirin%20Fozdar.htm | title = Shirin Fozdar: An Outstanding Pioneer | first = Anil | last = Sarwal | journal = Bahá'í Digest | year = 1989 | accessdate = 2008-02-23}} On March 15, she gave a public introduction to the Baha'i Faith in a lecture at the Norodom theatre, which was given significant coverage in the Vietnamese press.{{cite news|title=Vai tro Phu-nu trong trat-tu moi theo Ton-giao BA-HAI|newspaper=Saigon Moi|date=18 March 1954|page=1,3}} During this time, Pham Huu Chu, a professor living in Saigon, became the first Vietnamese Bahá'í.{{cite journal| title = Bahá'í News|date=February 1962 | page=14 | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | issn=0195-9212}} Jamshed and Parvati Fozdar, members of Fozdar's family, arrived to take her place in the summer, settling into an apartment at 88 Bonard St (now Le Loi St).{{sfn|Lộc|1972|p=79}}{{sfn|Baha'i Community of Vietnam|2004|p=8}} By the following year, there were enough Bahá'ís in Saigon to elect the country's first Local Spiritual Assembly there, on 21 April 1955.{{cite journal| title = Bahá'í News|date=July 1955 |page=5 | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | issn=0195-9212}} The Assembly was officially recognized by the government of South Vietnam on 20 September.{{sfn|Baha'i Community of Vietnam|2004|p=9}} Promotion of the religion in Central Vietnam led to the establishment of Vietnam's second Spiritual Assembly in the village of Trừng Giang,Now Hoà Giang village, Điện Trung commune, [[Điện Bàn District]], [[Quảng Nam province]]. [[Quảng Nam province]], in April 1957.{{cite journal| title = Bahá'í News|date=September 1957 |page=4 | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | issn=0195-9212}}{{cite web|title=Tìm hiểu về đạo Baha’i ở Việt Nam|trans-title=Learn about the Baha'i religion in Vietnam|url=http://www.mattran.org.vn/Home/TapChi/so%2057/hdll.htm|publisher=Central Committee of the Vietnamese Fatherland Front|accessdate=2012-10-09}} Eight more Spiritual Assemblies were established in 1958, bringing the total to ten. Of these, most were in Central Vietnam, including those of [[Da Nang]] and [[Quang Ngai]]. Also established in that year was the Bahá'í community of Phuoc Long, where the first Bahá'í school of South Vietnam was established; several other schools were established in Central Vietnam.{{cite journal|title=Progress of the Faith in Viet-Nam|journal=Bahá'í News Letter|publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of India, Pakistan & Burma|issue=85|date=August 1958}}{{cite journal| title = Bahá'í News|date=December 1958 |page=8 | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | issn=0195-9212}} In 1958 [[Tuskegee Airman]] Dempsey Morgan and his wife Adrienne, both Bahá'ís, came to Vietnam, and over succeeding years helped establish administrative procedures among the Local Spiritual Assemblies of Vietnam.{{cite book | first = Gwendolyn | last = Etter-Lewis |author2=Thomas, Richard Walter | year = 2006 | publisher = Baha'i Publishing Trust | isbn = 1-931847-26-6 | pages = 113–119 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=L2KVX4mx1xEC&pg=PA114&lpg=PA114&dq= | title = Lights of the Spirit: Historical Portraits of Black Bahá'ís in North America 1898–2000 }} During their stay in Vietnam, the Morgans also identified [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the founder of the Bahá'ís Faith, with the [[Maitreya Buddha]], who in the [[Buddhist]] tradition is the successor to [[Gautama Buddha]] and who is to appear on Earth, achieve complete [[Enlightenment (Buddhism)|enlightenment]], and teach the pure [[Dharma (Buddhism)|dharma]].{{cite web | title = Buddhism and the Baha'i Faith | first = Moojan | last = Momen | publisher = Baha'i Library Online | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_buddhism | accessdate = 2008-02-23 | date = 2 March 2002}} During this period of growth a number of Buddhist monks also become Baha'is. The Morgan family left Vietnam for Thailand in 1959, staying for two years before continuing to Phnom Penh. They were able to visit Saigon when [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] visited in 1961 and were able to move back to Saigon before the end of the year. There was also a local newsletter the ''Bahá'í News'' in publication by then. From 1957 to 1963 the Bahá'í community in South Vietnam had more than tripled (including among the [[K'Ho|Koho]], [[Thổ people|Thổ]], [[Vietnamese people|Annamese]], and [[Cham (Asia)|Cham]] peoples) and several schools were established.{{cite book |editor = Rabbani, R. |editor-link = Rúhíyyih Khanum |year = 1992 |title = The Ministry of the Custodians 1957–1963 |publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 138, 140, 360 |url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians |isbn = 0-85398-350-X}} In 1957 the [[Bahá'í marriage]] certificate was recognized in Vietnam.{{cite book |first = Shoghi |last = Effendi |authorlink = Shoghi Effendi |year = 1971 |title = Messages to the Bahá'í World, 1950–1957 |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-036-5 |url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/mbw-54.html.iso8859-1?#gr18 | page = 107}} In 1962 16 Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assemblies]] formed, and by 1963 there were more than 40 (and perhaps over 100) Spiritual Assemblies in South Vietnam.{{cite book | title = The Bahá'í Faith 1844–1963| url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63 | authors =Compiled by the Hands of the Cause Residing in the Holy Land | year = 1964 | page = 91}} By 1963 there were also 6 local Bahá'í Centers or [[Haziratu'l-Quds]], including in Saigon and [[Da Nang]], and more lands had been bought for future centers. As the number of Bahá'í Local Spiritual Assemblies increased, the [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the Bahá'ís of Vietnam was established in 1964.{{cite web | url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963| authors = Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land | pages = 22, 46}} One report estimated over 20,000 Bahá'ís nationwide by mid-1964, giving it the "third largest membership among the major religions" in South Vietnam at that time.{{cite news| title = Le Vietnam Nouveau | date=1964-07-07}} Although the Bahá'í community held a generally positive relationship with the government of [[Ngô Đình Diệm]], there is evidence of sporadic opposition at different levels during this period. One account describes government harassment of the Vietnamese Bahá'ís around 1958–59, including the imprisonment of the entire Spiritual Assembly of Saigon. On 21 April 1963, Bui Van Luong, then Diệm's Interior Minister, formally prohibited Bahá'ís from pursuing "any religious activities in Central Vietnam and the mountainous provinces." Seven months later, the Diệm government was [[1963 South Vietnamese coup|overthrown]], and the prohibition of Bahá'í activities was annulled.{{cite news|title=Buddhists March in VN; No Violence Is Reported|newspaper=The Bangkok Post|volume=19|number=115|date=21 May 1963}}{{cite journal| title = Bahá'í News|date=August 1964 | page=4 | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | issn=0195-9212}} An account reported in a Swiss Bahá'í newsletter in February 1964 claimed that Bahá'ís in Vietnam had been subject to harassment for over seven years leading up to Diệm's ouster.{{cite journal| title = Bulletin d'Informations Bahá'íes de Suisse|trans-title=Switzerland Bahá'í News Bulletin|date=February 1964 |page=7 }} ===Post-Diệm era (1963–1975)=== As the [[Vietnam war]] continued, there were a number of [[United States|American]] Bahá'ís who were stationed in Vietnam, but following the Bahá'í teaching of the sacredness of all life and of obedience to one's government, Bahá'ís would request to avoid being placed in a position to take the life of another, and thus American Bahá'ís served as clerks and medics as [[non-combatants]].{{cite book | title = Religious Dimensions of Child and Family Life: Reflections on the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child | chapter = Child and Family in Baha'i Religion| first = John | last = Hatcher | editor = Coward, Harold G. |editorlink=Harold Coward | year = 1996 | publisher = University of Victoria | location = Victoria, B.C. | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JD8_s94htQMC&pg=PA159&lpg=PA159&dq | pages = 141–160 | isbn = 978-1-55058-104-1 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.bahai.us/node/77 |title=Selected profiles of African-American Baha'is, William H. "Smitty" Smith |date=28 June 2006 |accessdate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927092140/http://www.bahai.us/node/77 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df=dmy }}{{cite web | url = http://www.veteransforpeace.org/Nikko_schoch_tribute.vp.html | title = About Veterans for Peace: Remembrance of Nikko Schoch | first = Frank Barry | last = Smith | accessdate = 2008-02-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080212230505/http://www.veteransforpeace.org/Nikko_schoch_tribute.vp.html| archivedate= 12 February 2008 | deadurl= no}}{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=t57XsKWhb1QC&pg=PA191 | chapter = Becoming a Man | first = Sidney | last = Morrison, | title = Equal Circles: Women and Men in the Baha'i Community | editor = Caton, Peggy | year = 1987 | publisher = Kalimat Press | isbn = 0-933770-28-6 | page = 199}} By April 1973, 687 Local Spiritual Assemblies had been formed, and Bahá'ís could be found in 1,685 localities. By 1975, there were an estimated 200,000 Bahá'ís in South Vietnam, and the Bahá'í community and its institutions were still experiencing growth.{{cite book|title=The Bahá'í World|volume=16|year=1978|publisher=Bahá'í World Centre|location=Haifa|author=The Universal House of Justice|isbn=0853980756|page=262}} ==Communist Vietnam (post-1975)== [[File:HoChiMinhCity01c.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A billboard commemorates the 30th anniversary of the reunification of Vietnam.]]In the chaos following the [[Fall of Saigon]] on April 30, 1975, the Bahá'í community was severely limited logistically. Contact had already been lost with members in outlying areas, and the national convention scheduled for that time was cancelled; the National Spiritual Assembly was instead elected via mailed-in ballots.{{sfn|Baha'i Community of Vietnam|2004|p=30-31,55}} In a 1978 report, the [[Universal House of Justice]] noted that
"In the latter part of the period under review [1973-1976] circumstances beyond the control of the Bahá'ís have hindered the completion of the goals. An administrative committee has been appointed to function on behalf of the National Spiritual Assembly.
For a time, the incoming communist government seemed to tolerate Bahá'í activities; Bahá'ís in the newly renamed Ho Chi Minh City (previously Saigon) were allowed to hold a commemoration of the Martyrdom of the Báb in July 1976, and following the setbacks of the previous years, a meeting was held the following year to elect a National Spiritual Assembly. ===Official proscription=== {{See also|Freedom of religion in Vietnam}} Beginning in 1978, open practice of the Bahá'í Faith in Vietnam was officially proscribed. Bahá'ís were forbidden to meet or to practice their religion, and Bahá'í properties throughout the country were closed or confiscated. Two members of the National Spiritual Assembly who were present when the national headquarters in Ho Chi Minh City was confiscated were arrested and sent to [[Re-education camp (Vietnam)|reeducation camps]].{{cite book|title=The Bahá'í World|volume=18|year=1986|publisher=Bahá'í World Centre|location=Haifa|author=The Universal House of Justice|isbn=0853982341|pages=96–97}}{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} In a message sent a year later, the Universal House of Justice reported that Vietnam was among "those countries where the Bahá'í Administration cannot operate or has had to be disbanded".{{cite web|url=http://bahai-library.com/uhj_naw-ruz_1979|title=Launching of the Seven Year Plan|author=The Universal House of Justice|year=1979|accessdate=2012-09-28}} Community numbers dropped sharply during this time as thousands of Bahá'ís fled the country, arriving as refugees in the United States and other countries, where efforts were made to contact and integrate them into local Bahá'í communities.{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QT3i34vGS-cC&pg=PA127&lpg=PA127&dq= | title = The Routledge Historical Atlas of Religion in America| first = Bret E. | last = Carroll | page = 127 | isbn = 0-415-92131-7 | publisher = Routledge | year = 2000}} Bahá'ís in a number of countries throughout the world began sending support to those Bahá'ís who remained in Vietnam, regularly sending parcels of medicine, clothes and other necessities; some were able to visit the country and meet with Bahá'ís personally. The Bahá'ís who remained in Vietnam made appeals to the government requesting the permission to practice their religion and the return of confiscated properties, although progress was limited. At the same time, appeals for the release of Bahá'í prisoners continued, through the [[Bahá'í International Community]] and a number of governments and independent agencies. In March 1986, a copy of the Universal House of Justice's statement, ''[[The Promise of World Peace]]'', was delivered by a messenger to Mr. Bui Xuan Nhat, the Permanent Representative of Vietnam to the United Nations.Bahá'í News, Feb. 1988. The 1990s and early 2000s saw conditions improve gradually. In 1990, [[Collis Featherstone|H. Collis Featherstone]], a [[Hand of the Cause]], visited Vietnam, focusing his efforts on "reinvigorating" the Bahá'ís there.Ridván message, 1990. Universal House of Justice. Beginning in 1992, Bahá'ís were allowed to meet in unofficial meeting halls to practice their religion quietly, and the first Bahá'í group was established in Hanoi.{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2005/51535.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report — Vietnam | year = 2005 | accessdate = 2012-09-25 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}} In 1996, the Universal House of Justice sent a message to Bahá'ís in a number of Southeast Asian countries, particularly calling "the sorely tried, steadfast and devoted friends" in Vietnam to demonstrate to the authorities and to their leaders that "Bahá'ís, obedient and loyal to their governments, desire but the prosperity of their nations and the upliftment of their peoples."{{cite web|url=http://bahai-library.com/published.uhj/ridvan/96camb.html|title=Ridván Message, B.E. 153|author=The Universal House of Justice|date=21 April 1996|accessdate=2012-09-28}} In 2000, Bahá'ís in [[Da Nang]] were reportedly unable to obtain approval of an application for registration of official religious activities,{{cite web | last = compiled by Wagner | first = Ralph D. | title = VIETNAM | work = Synopsis of References to the Bahá'í Faith, in the US State Department's Reports on Human Rights 1991–2000 | publisher = Bahá'í Academics Resource Library | url = http://bahai-library.com/documents/hr/hr-vietnam.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-04}} and in 2001, the Vietnamese government reportedly turned down an attempt by the national Bahá'í community to register its activities because they "had not yet met the administrative criteria for registration."{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2003/24327.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report — Vietnam | year = 2003 | accessdate = 2012-09-25 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}} The difficulties encountered by the Bahá'í community were far from unique. While Vietnam had ratified the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]](ICCPR) which has provisions for religious freedom (Article 18),{{cite web | url = http://www.uniya.org/research/view_vietnam.html | title = View on Vietnam | first = Lyndall J. |last = Stoyles | date = November 2004 | publisher = Uniya Jesuit Social Justice Centre | accessdate = 2008-02-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080209231245/http://www.uniya.org/research/view_vietnam.html| archivedate= 9 February 2008 | deadurl= no}} and its own [[Constitution of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam|Constitution]] upholds religious freedom,"The citizen shall enjoy freedom of belief or religion; he can follow any religion or none. All religions are equal before the law. The places of worship of all faiths and religions are protected by the law. No one can violate freedom of belief and of religion; nor can anyone misuse belief and religion to contravene the law and State policies." Article 70, [[Constitution of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam]]. 1992. the U.S. State Department reported in its ''2001 International Religious Freedom Report'' that the Vietnamese government "continued to restrict" certain organized activities of religious groups, noting that "many of these restrictive powers lie principally with provincial or city people's committees, and local treatment of religious persons varied widely."{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2001/5692.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report — Vietnam | year = 2001 | accessdate = 2012-09-25 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}}"Only religions that have been officially recognised have legal rights. To be authorised, the group must obtain Government approval of its leadership and overall scope of its activities. Failure to comply leads to persecution. The Government retains supervisory control of authorised religions. All religious organisations have to be affiliated with the [[Communist Party of Vietnam]] and an organisation called the Patriotic Front [i.e. [[Vietnamese Fatherland Front]]]. Government permission is required for many religious practices, including general meetings, charitable activities, operation of schools and ordination and promotion of clergy and travel outside the country. Religious training must be approved by the State and must promote the policy of “socialism”. State approved churches are also required to promote Government policies on a wide range of issues." {{cite web | url = http://www.uniya.org/research/view_vietnam.html | title = View on Vietnam | first = Lyndall J. |last = Stoyles | date = November 2004 | publisher = Uniya Jesuit Social Justice Centre | accessdate = 2008-02-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080209231245/http://www.uniya.org/research/view_vietnam.html| archivedate= 9 February 2008 | deadurl= no}} ===End of proscription and recent developments=== [[File:Baha'i nat'l election Danang 2009.jpg|thumb|right|Vietnamese Bahá’ís elect their National Spiritual Assembly in [[Danang]], in 2009.]] With time, the fortunes of the Vietnamese Bahá'í community continued to improve. Bahá'ís in Ho Chi Minh City were allowed to hold a quiet ceremony in May 2004 to mark the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the Baha'i Faith in the country. By 2006, Bahá'í community leaders reported having "good relations with authorities", and that the Bahá'ís "appeared to be able to practice their faith without significant harassment." In November of that year, the US State Department reported that restrictions were being eased.{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2006/71363.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report — Vietnam | year = 2006 | accessdate = 2012-09-25 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}}{{cite web | url = http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2006/November/20061114150908mlenuhret0.4384882.html | title = Vietnam Praised, Uzbekistan Faulted on Religious Freedom | first = Lea | last= Terhune | publisher = Bureau of International Information Programs, U.S. Department of State | date = 14 November 2006 | accessdate = 2008-02-23}} Finally, after many years of progress, the Bahá'í community was officially registered in early 2007, receiving a certificate of operation from the governmental Committee for Religious Affairs.{{cite web | url = http://vietnamnews.vnagency.com.vn/showarticle.php?num=01REL220307 | title = Nation's Baha'i community gets religious recognition | date = 22 March 2007 | publisher = Viet Nam News, Vietnam News Agency | location = Hanoi, Vietnam | accessdate = 2008-02-23}} Following a year-long probationary period, its nine-member National Spiritual Assembly was elected and its charter adopted on 21 March 2008, at a national congress in [[Ho Chi Minh City]] coinciding with the Bahá'í holy day of [[Bahá'í Naw-Rúz|Naw-Rúz]]. The event was attended by over 250 delegates and visitors.{{cite news | author = Vietnam News Agency | title = Baha’i sect receives legal recognition | work = VietNamNet Bridge | publisher = VietNamNet Bridge | date = 22 March 2008 | url = http://english.vietnamnet.vn/social/2008/03/774707/ | accessdate =2008-03-24 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080327203224/http://english.vietnamnet.vn/social/2008/03/774707/ |archivedate = 27 March 2008}} The National Spiritual Assembly received its certificate of national recognition in July 2008, setting the stage for Local Spiritual Assemblies to be registered as well.{{cite news | author = Vietnam News Agency | title = Baha’i community recognised as religious organisation | work = VietNamNet Bridge | publisher = VietNamNet Bridge | date = 26 July 2008 | url = http://english.vietnamnet.vn/politics/2008/07/795619/ | accessdate = 2008-0-27}} With previous restrictions relaxed, the Vietnamese Bahá’í Community has continued to achieve marked progress, returning to a normal pace of activities and showing signs of growth in size, in freedom, and in institutional capacity. Soon after their community's recognition, Vietnamese Bahá'ís were granted permission to attend a major regional conference in [[Battambang|Battambang, Cambodia]], attended by over 2,000 of their co-religionists from Cambodia, Laos and Thailand.http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/battambang.html National conventions, held annually in various regions, continue to gather delegates and observers in the hundreds for the election of the National Spiritual Assembly. The fourth national convention, held in April 2011 in the southern city of [[Phan Thiet]], gathered more than 300 Bahá’í members. The Vietnamese government also allowed members from other nations in the region, including representatives from the Bahá’í Advisory Board for Asia and its Board of Trustees for Southeast Asia, to join the event and actively participate for the first time.{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2011/eap/192677.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report—Vietnam | year = 2011 | accessdate = 2012-09-25 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}} In May 2012, government officials granted 20 Bahá’ís permission to participate in their first collective [[Bahá'í pilgrimage|pilgrimage]] to the [[Bahá'í World Center]] in [[Haifa|Haifa, Israel]]. The nine-day pilgrimage allowed them to visit religious shrines and meet with fellow believers. In August of the same year, the Bahá’ís of Hanoi celebrated the 20th anniversary of the religion's establishment in that city with a day-long public celebration, attended by nearly 100 followers from the northern area of the country, 20 foreign Bahá’ís representing countries in the region, and government officials. In May 2013, Vietnamese Bahá’ís were able to send delegates to represent their country at the 11th International Bahá'í Convention in Haifa, where they participated in the election of the Universal House of Justice.http://www.nhipcautamgiao.net/tintuc/4811-chia-se-ve-dai-hoi-bahai-quoc-te-lan-thu-11.html Later in the same year, a number of Vietnamese Bahá'í youth joined their counterparts in Cambodia at a youth conference in Battambang.''[http://news.bahai.org/community-news/youth-conferences/battambang.html Battambang Youth Conference]''. Bahá’í International Community. Although the 2005 World Christian Database estimated the Bahá'í population of Vietnam well above 300,000,{{cite web | url = http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_bahai.html | publisher = Adherents.com | title = The Largest Baha'i Communities | accessdate = 2008-02-23 | date = 30 September 2005| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080222012133/http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_bahai.html| archivedate= 22 February 2008 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} the U.S. State Department estimated the Bahá'í population at around 8,000 in 2012. Regardless, the 2015 estimate from the World Religion Database, the direct successor to the World Christian Database, was of 413,000 Bahá'ís.{{cite book | editor1=Brian Grim |editor2=Todd Johnson |editor3= Vegard Skirbekk |editor4= Gina Zurlo | title =Yearbook of International Religious Demography 2016 | publisher = Brill | series =Yearbook of International Religious Demography | volume =3 | date =2016 | pages =17–25 | url =http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/books/9789004322141 | doi =10.1163/9789004322141 | isbn =9789004322141 }} ==See also== *[[Bahá'í Faith by country]] *[[Religion in Vietnam]] *[[List of ethnic groups in Vietnam]] ==Notes and references== ;Notes {{reflist|2}} ;References {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book| title=Lược Sử Tôn Giáo Baha'i Tại Việt Nam: 50 Năm - Một Chặng Đường, 1954-2004|trans-title=The History of the Baha'i Faith in Vietnam: 50 Years - One Way, 1954-2004 | publisher=Baha'i Community of Vietnam | year=2004 | pages=76|language = Vietnamese|ref=harv}} *{{cite book| title=Baha'i Là Gì?|trans-title=What Is Baha'i? | author=Lê Lộc | publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Vietnam | year=1972 | pages=248|language = Vietnamese|ref=harv}} {{Refend}} ==External links== *[http://www.bahai.org.vn/ Baha'i Community of Vietnam] {{vi icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091027094202/http://geocities.com/bahaisvietnam/ An individual's webpage about the Baha'is in Vietnam] {{vi icon}} {{Asia topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith In Vietnam}} [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|Vietnam]] [[Category:Religion in Vietnam]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox newspaper |name = Der Tog |foundation = 1914 |type = daily newspaper |headquarters = [[Lower East Side]] 185 and 187 East Broadway, [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|USA]] |publishing_country = United States |language = [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]] |ceased publication = 1971 }} '''''Der Tog''''' ({{lang-en|The Day}}) was a Yiddish-language daily newspaper published in New York City from 1914 until 1971. The offices of ''Der Tog'' were located on the [[Lower East Side]], at 185 and 187 East Broadway.<ref>Sanders, Ronald. ''The Lower East Side: A Guide to Its Jewish Past in 99 New Photographs''. Mineola, NY: Dover Publications, 2013 (first published 1979). 67.</ref>
== History == The newspaper's first issue was on November 5, 1914.<ref name="NYPLBulletin">"[https://books.google.com/books?id=Uob7MIjq1woC&pg=PA563&lpg=PA563&dq=%22der+tog%22+yiddish+%22new+York+city%22++1914&source=bl&ots=T2cwFosW6T&sig=7jwHV2bm7l7kR7j7IfgIBoz8Lr4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AbiAU_aWA9bJsQS1_4GwDw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22der%20tog%22&f=false A Checklist of Newspapers and Official Gazettes in the New York Public Library]." ''Bulletin of the New York Public Library''. Vol. 19, Part 2 (1915): 563.</ref> At its peak ''Der Tog'' reached a circulation of 81,000, in 1916.<ref name="Halkin">Halkin, Hillel. "Jewish Day." ''Encyclopaedia Judaica''. Ed. Michael Berenbaum and Fred Skolnik. 2nd ed. Vol. 11. Detroit: Macmillan Reference USA, 2007. 290</ref> It had a weekly English-language supplement entitled ''The Day'',<ref name="NYPLBulletin"/> edited by Marion Weinstein.<ref name="JTA1929">"'[http://www.jta.org/1929/11/12/archive/day-yiddish-daily-marks-15th-anniversary Day' Yiddish Daily, Marks 15th Anniversary]." ''Jewish Telegraphic Agency'', 12 November 1929.</ref> In 1919 ''Der Tog'' absorbed another Yiddish newspaper, ''Di Varhayt'' (Warheit; Wahrheit; "The Truth"),<ref name="Halkin"/> and between 1919 and 1922 was known as ''Der Tog, di Varhayt''.<ref>Caliendo, Ralph J. ''New York City Mayors. Part I: The Mayors of New York Before 1898''. "[https://books.google.com/books?id=mNe7Sph7lJ8C&pg=PA489&lpg=PA489&dq=%22di+varhayt%22&source=bl&ots=whYaLEbCUZ&sig=fM7zKbLvRoKXqwRXWNbUgFTQBOI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XtGAU8XIIemysASN74GgBA&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22di%20varhayt%22&f=false Foreign-Language Daily Newspapers in New York City]," 489. </ref><ref>"[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045860/ About Der Tog, di ṿarhayṭ = The Day, the Warheit. (New York, N.Y.) 1919-1922]." Library of Congress, Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers.</ref>
In 1953 ''Der Tog'' merged with the [[Jewish Morning Journal | ''Morgn Zshurnal'']] (Morning Journal), and subsequently appeared under the title ''Der Tog Morgn Zshurnal''; the circulation was estimated at 50,000 in 1970, and the paper ceased publication in 1971.<ref name="Halkin"/>
It was followed by [[Der Algemeiner Journal]] in 1972.
== Journalists and Writers == The founding of the newspaper was the project of a group of businessmen and intellectuals including [[Judah Leon Magnes |Judah Leib Magnes]]<!-- Judah Leon and Judah Leib maybe were not the same person-->, David Shapiro,<ref>Documents related to the founding of the newspaper are contained in the [http://www.yivoarchives.org/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=34321&top=1 Papers of David Shapiro], held at the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research (RG 1912); Newman, Roberta. "[http://www.yivo.org/blog/index.php/2014/01/24/portrait-of-a-collection-the-david-shapiro-papers-in-the-yivo-archives/ Portrait of a Collection: The David Shapiro Papers in the YIVO Archives]" [blog entry]. ''Yedies fun YIVO / News from YIVO''. 24 January 2014.</ref> Morris Weinberg, and [[Herman Bernstein]]. Bernstein became the paper's first editor and Shapiro assumed the role of publisher.<ref name="JTA1929"/><ref> Sometime later on, after Shapiro's death, in 1940, Morris Weinberg became the publisher; "'[http://www.jta.org/1954/11/16/archive/der-tog-american-jewish-newspaper-celebrates-40th-anniversary Der Tog' American Jewish Newspaper Celebrates Its 40th Anniversary]. ''Jewish Telegraphic Agency'', 16 November 1954.</ref> Styled in its masthead as a "newspaper for the Jewish intelligentsia,"<ref name="Halkin"/><ref name="Passow26">Passow, David. ''The Prime of Yiddish''. New York: Geffen Books, 1996. 26.</ref> ''Der Tog'' sought to uphold high journalistic and literary standards, and to rise above ideological divides.
Under [[William Edlin]], who succeeded Bernstein as editor in 1916, and the first literary editor, Benzion Hoffman (Zivion),<ref name="Cohen161">Cohen, Nathan. "The Yiddish Press and Yiddish Literature: a Fertile But Complex Relationship." ''Modern Judaism'' 20.2 (May 2008): 149-172; here: 161.</ref> the newspaper attracted a talented staff, including [[Shmuel Niger]], who was its literary critic for many years.<ref name="Halkin"/><ref name="Cohen161"/>
Among the other outstanding staff writers were [[David Pinski]], Aron Glanz (A. Leyeles), Joel Slonim, [[Peretz Hirshbein]], and Abraham Coralnik.<ref name="Halkin"/> Other significant contributors included [[Chaim Zhitlowsky]] and Samuel Rosenfeld,<ref name="Passow26"/> as well as [[H. Leivick]], [[Osip Dymov (writer)|Osip Dymov]], and Ruven Ayzland.<ref name="Cohen161"/> [[Leon Kobrin]] was the paper's chief fiction writer for nearly two decades;<ref name="Passow27">Passow, 27.</ref> and among the more famous of other occasional literary contributors were [[Joseph Opatoshu]] and [[Avrom Reyzen | Abraham Reisen]].<ref>Passow, 26-27.</ref> The newspaper also published the entirety of the Bible translation by the poet [[Yehoash (Blumgarten) | Yehoash]] (pseudonym of Solomon Bloomgarden), and some works of [[Sholem Aleichem]].<ref name="Passow27"/>
Edlin, who had been associated with the paper from its beginnings as a news editor and a theater critic, remained editor in chief until 1925. [[Samuel Margoshes]] filled that role from 1926 until 1942.<ref name="Edlin75yor">Edlin, William. "Der 'Tog' – di tsaytung, vos hot arayngebrakht a nayem ton in der idisher prese" ('Der Tog,' a newspaper that brought a new tone to the Yiddish press). ''75 yor yidishe prese in Amerike, 1870-1945''. Ed. J. Gladstone, S. Niger, and H. Rogoff. New York: The I. L. Peretz Yiddish Writers Union, 1945. 69-75; here: 72 (editors' note).</ref> At that point Edlin came back and led the paper again,<ref name="Edlin75yor"/> until his death, in 1947.<ref>"[http://www.jta.org/1947/12/01/archive/william-edlin-editor-of-jewish-day-dies-was-69-years-old William Edlin, Editor of Jewish Day, Dies; Was 69 Years Old]," ''Jewish Telegraphic Agency'', 1 December 1947.</ref>
According to Edlin, ''Der Tog'' was the first Yiddish newspaper to include female journalists on the editorial staff. Adella Kean-Sametkin wrote about women's issues, and Dr. Ida Badanes, about health matters; the popular fiction writer Sarah B. Smith was also a regular contributor over many years.<ref>Edlin, 72; also cited in: Rojanski, Rachel, "Socialist Ideology, Traditional Rhetoric: Images of Women in American Yiddish Socialist Dailies, 1918-1922." ''American Jewish History'' 93.3 (September 2007): 329-348; here: 342.</ref> Before making her mark as a poet, [[Anna Margolin]] (pseudonym of Rosa Lebensboym) distinguished herself as a reporter and editor for ''Der Tog'', contributing a column, "In der froyen velt" (In the women's world), under her actual name, and articles about women's issues under various pseudonyms, including Clara Levin.<ref>Brenner, Naomi. "Slippery Selves: Rachel Bluvstein and Anna Margolin in Poetry and in Public." ''Nashim: A Journal of Jewish Women's Studies & Gender Issues'' No. 19 (Spring 2010): 100-133; here: 112.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.yivoarchives.org/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=32998 ''Guide to the Records of the Day-Morning Journal ("Der Tog")'', 1922-1972], YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, RG 639. *[http://www.yivoarchives.org/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=33697 ''Guide to the Papers of Herman Morgenstern'', 1914-1976], YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, RG 1334. Morgenstern was a reporter and editor for ''Der Tog - Morgn Zshurnal'' from 1938 to 1971.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tog, Der}} [[Category:Yiddish newspapers]] [[Category:Defunct newspapers of New York City]] [[Category:Yiddish-language newspapers published in the United States]] [[Category:Yiddish culture in New York City]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=December 2012}} {{Primary sources|date=December 2017}} }} '''The Doctor''' is the name of several fictional characters in the [[Wildstorm Universe]]. ==Doctor lineage== The Doctors are a lineage of humans who are chosen by the Earth to serve as its shaman.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} Each Doctor inherits the position the second their predecessor dies.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} When a Doctor dies, their soul joins the Garden of Ancestral Memory, a spiritual realm{{Citation needed|date=November 2012}} where the current Doctor can commune with their predecessors.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} ==Fictional character biographies== ===First Doctor=== The first of the modern-day Doctors, an African-American, was a member of a group called the [[Changers (Wildstorm)|Changers]], who were led by the superhero the [[High (comics)|High]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} The group's plan was to change the world by removing the structure of society itself, eliminating all crime and war in the process. The Doctor's part in the group's plan was to initiate a program of public education about the world's natural resources, such as plants and magic. However, [[Stormwatch (comics)|Stormwatch]] attacked the group's base with a tailored acid bomb that killed the Doctor and his companions.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} This Doctor was seen several times afterward in the Garden of Ancestral Memory and advised Thornedike whenever needed.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} ===Renegade Doctor=== In 1966, a heart surgeon became the Doctor.''The Authority'' (vol. 1) #18 (Oct. 2000) After acquiring his powers, the Doctor slaughtered the entire population of three countries (in alphabetical order) and fell asleep after drinking every bottle of [[Dom Pérignon (wine)|Dom Pérignon]] in existence at the time.''The Authority'' (vol. 1) #20 (Jan. 2001) The Doctor was defeated when every active superhero on Earth joined forces to defeat him. The Doctor was stripped of his powers and imprisoned in a pocket dimension 20 million years in the past. However, the renegade Doctor communicated with the Earth in the present day from his prison and convinced the planet that humanity was killing it, causing mass devastation to places such as New York City and the [[Vatican City|Vatican]].''The Authority'' (vol. 1) #17 (Sept. 2000) Jeroen Thornedike, the then-current Doctor, was forced to give his powers back to his predecessor for an hour in order to fix the damage to the Earth.''The Authority'' (vol. 1) #19 (Nov. 2000) After regaining his powers, the renegade Doctor was brought into the present where he fought the Authority. During the fight, he travelled into the past and retroactively molested the Engineer as a teenager. As he was about to win the fight, the Doctor developed fifteen extra senses, including [[empathy]] with every living creature on the planet, which overwhelmed him. Apollo and the Engineer then used the distraction from the enhanced sensory input to behead the Doctor. {{clear}} ===Jeroen Thornedike=== {{Infobox comics character |image= |caption= |character_name=The Doctor |real_name=Jeroen Thornedike |publisher=[[Wildstorm]] |debut=''The Authority'' (vol. 1) #1 (May 1999) |creators=[[Warren Ellis]]
[[Bryan Hitch]] |alliances=[[The Authority (comics)|The Authority]] |previous_alliances= |aliases= |powers=Reality warping }} '''Jeroen Thornedike''' was a Dutch former dot-com billionaire who became the Doctor after his predecessor died. At first, Jeroen refused to accept the responsibility and spent his days shooting [[heroin]] and playing [[Sonic the Hedgehog series|Sonic the Hedgehog]].''Jenny Sparks: The Secret History of the Authority'' #1 (Aug. 2000) [[Jenny Sparks]] and [[Swift (comics)|Swift]] attempted to recruit him into the Authority. However, Jeroen refused and teleported them away; Sparks again attempted to recruit him, shooting herself in the head to force Jeroen to use his powers to heal her. Jeroen then joined the Authority. Jeroen married Courtney, a rock star, and overdosed on heroin while on his honeymoon, causing him to fall into a trance while disasters struck around the world. Jeroen was cured of his heroin addiction when Midnighter gave him a transfusion of his blood. Jeroen was later forced to relinquish his powers to the renegade Doctor in order to save the Earth and regained them when the renegade Doctor was killed. Soon afterwards, Jeroen was defeated and stripped of his powers, which were then given to The Surgeon, a modern-day French [[alchemy|alchemist]]''The Authority'' (vol. 1) #27 (Jan. 2002) The Surgeon turned Jeroen into a doll and carried him in his pockets, using him to scrub out stains from the Surgeon's underpants. The Surgeon brought corporate contractors into the Garden of Ancestral Memory, who murdered the entities living there and later supervised the creation of a corporate religion called "Religimon". The Surgeon was later killed by Midnighter and Jeroen instantly recovered his powers.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} Thornedike died from a drug overdose given to him by [[Rose Tattoo (Wildstorm)|Rose Tattoo]] and his soul was captured by [[Henry Bendix]] to locate the next Doctor, Habib Ben Hassan.''The Authority: Revolution'' #9 (June 2005) Jeroen’s soul was later freed by [[Jenny Quantum]], where it then moved on and joined his predecessors in the Garden of Ancestral Memory.''The Authority: Revolution'' #10 (July 2005) {{clear}} ===Habib ben Hassan=== {{Infobox comics character |image=Habib.PNG |caption=Habib ben Hassan as the Doctor. Art by [[Gene Ha]]. |character_name=The Doctor |real_name=Habib Ben Hassan |publisher=[[Wildstorm]] |debut=''The Authority: Revolution'' #9 (June 2005) |creators=[[Ed Brubaker]]
[[Dustin Nguyen (artist)|Dustin Nguyen]] |alliances=[[The Authority (comics)|The Authority]] |previous_alliances= |aliases= The Green Man |powers=Reality warping }} Habib ben Hassan was a young Palestinian suicide bomber. Within the first 24 hours of inheriting his powers after Thornedike's death, Habib engineered a peace in the Middle East that actually had a chance of succeeding until he was captured by [[Henry Bendix]] and imprisoned in a cell which cut him off from his powers. He was secretly freed by [[Jenny Quantum]] and joined in the battle with Bendix and his followers. During the fight, Habib redeemed Rose Tattoo, transforming her from the Spirit of Murder to the Spirit of Life.''The Authority: Revolution'' #12 (Sept. 2005) Sometime later, Habib was unable to stop a cadre of clones of the High from damaging the Carrier, causing it to crash into London.''Number of the Beast'' #8 (Sept. 2008) After witnessing the end of the world soon afterwards, Habib committed suicide by jumping from the Carrier and dissolving into butterflies.''The Authority'' (vol. 5) #10 (July 2009) Habib later appeared alongside Jeroen to Midnighter in a dream, ordering him to find something capable of healing the world.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} However, Habib's consciousness, badly traumatised by the Earth's present condition, manipulated Gaia Rothstein into turning herself into an island and then built itself a new body out of the vegetables and plant life from Gaia's island form.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} Now calling himself the Green Man, Habib vowed to save the Earth by wiping humanity from the face of the planet. Midnighter freed Gaia from Habib's enslavement and sent Habib's consciousness to the Garden of Ancestral Memory, causing the Green Man's body to collapse.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} The Wildcats then searched for Habib's successor as the Doctor with the help of the spirit of former Doctor Edwin Makepeace.''Wildcats'' (vol. 5) #28 (May 2010) ===Shen Li-Min=== Authority member Shen Li-Min (a.k.a. [[Swift (comics)|Swift]]), former friend of the last Doctor, was chosen as Habib's successor as she possessed a connection to the planet's ecosystem.''The Authority'' vol. 4 #29 (January 2011) ===The Surgeon=== During the "Transfer of Power" story arc, the members of the Authority were temporarily replaced with analogues that had roughly the same powers; the Surgeon was the Doctor's analogue.''The Authority'' #22 (March 2001). DC Comics. ==Powers and abilities== Each Doctor has the ability to alter reality by imagining something and causing reality to build it for them. As part of their position, each Doctor possesses fifteen extra senses, including empathy with every living creature on Earth. However, a Doctor's powers are disrupted if they are startled or distracted.''The Authority'' (vol. 1) #7 (Nov. 1999) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070120170846/http://www.internationalhero.co.uk/d/doctor.htm International Hero link] {{Authority}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Doctor, The}} [[Category:Characters created by Ed Brubaker]] [[Category:Characters created by Warren Ellis]] [[Category:Comics characters who use magic]] [[Category:Fictional African-American people]] [[Category:Fictional physicians]] [[Category:Fictional shamans]] [[Category:Fictional surgeons]] [[Category:Stormwatch and the Authority characters]] [[Category:Wildstorm Universe superheroes]]

{{see also|Turkish carpet}} [[File:Phoenix and dragon carpet Anatolia first half or middle 15th century.jpg|thumb|Phoenix and Dragon carpet, 164 x 91 cm, Anatolia, circa 1500, [[Pergamon Museum]], Berlin]] [[File:Marby carpet.jpg|thumb|Animal carpet, around 1500, found in Marby Church, [[Jämtland]], [[Sweden]]. Wool, 160 cm x 112 cm, [[Swedish History Museum]], Stockholm]] [[File:Unknown, Turkey, 11th-13th Century - Carpet with Animal Design - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Animal carpet, Turkey, dated to the 11th–13th century, [[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]]]] [[File:Armenian Animal carpet.jpg|thumb|Anatolian Animal carpet, 1500 or earlier, wool, symmetric knots. Pergamon Museum Inv. No. KGM 1885, 984]] [[File:Crivelli carpet Anatolia late 15th early 16th century.jpg|thumb|"Batári-Crivelli" rug, Anatolia, 15th century, [[Museum of Applied Arts (Budapest)]]]]
'''Anatolian animal carpets''' represent a special type of pile-woven [[Turkish carpet|carpet]], woven in the geographical region of Anatolia during the [[Seljuq dynasty|Seljuq]] and early [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] period, corresponding to the 14th–16th century. Very few animal-style carpets still exist today, and most of them are in a fragmentary state. Animal carpets were frequently depicted by Western European painters of the 14th–16th century. By comparison of the few surviving carpets with their painted counterparts, these paintings helped to establish a timeline of their production, and support our knowledge about the early Turkish carpet.<ref name="Erdmann, Seven Hundred Years of Oriental Carpets, 1970">{{Cite book|author=Erdmann, Kurt|year=1970|title=Seven Hundred Years of Oriental Carpets|location=Berkeley, California|publisher=University of California Press (translated from the German ''Siebenhundert Jahre Orientteppich'' by May H. Beattie and Hildegard Herzog)|isbn=9780520018167}}</ref>
== Surviving carpets ==
=== Dragon and Phoenix carpet === A traditional Chinese motif, the fight between the [[fenghuang]], or Chinese [[phoenix (mythology)|phoenix]], and the dragon, is seen in an Anatolian carpet at the [[Pergamon Museum]], Berlin. [[Radiocarbon dating]] confirmed that the "Dragon and Phoenix" carpet was woven in the mid 15th century, during the early [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rageth|first1=Jürg|title=Dating the dragon & phoenix fragments.|journal=Hali|date=2004|volume=134|pages=106–109}}</ref> It is knotted with symmetric knots.<ref name="Beselin, 2011">{{cite book|last1=Beselin|first1=Anna|title=Geknüpfte Kunst : Teppiche des Museums für Islamische Kunst = Woven Art: Carpets of the Berlin Museum of Islamic art|date=2011|publisher=Edition Minerva|location=Wolfratshausen|isbn=9783938832806|pages=46–47}}</ref> The Chinese motif was probably introduced into [[Islamic art]] by the Mongols, or artists working for them, during the thirteenth century.<ref name="Dragon and Phoenix carpet">{{cite web|title=Dragon and Phoenix Carpet|url=http://www.discoverislamicart.org/database_item.php?id=object;ISL;de;Mus01;34;de|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
The Dragon and Phoenix carpet lacks his original borders, and seems to be cut off at the right side. Its field is parted into two rectangular sections, each containing a yellow-groud octagon in which a Chinese dragon and a phoenix are opposed to each other in combat. Both animals are stylized in geometrical form. Their blue colours, outlined in red, contrasts well with the yellow ground of the octagon. The design of the upper octagon appears to be somewhat more compressed than the lower. The corners between the octagon and the rectangular field are filled in with red triangles and rows of white hooks on red ground, creating a reciprocal hook design. The rectangular fields are surrounded by a small guardian border showing a row of pearls in different colours. The main border has red floral tendrils composed of identical, S-like ornaments on a brown ground.<ref name="Beselin, 2011"/>
The Phoenix and Dragon carpet was first described in 1881 by [[Julius Lessing]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lessing|first1=Julius|title=Orientalische Teppiche = Oriental Carpets|date=1891|publisher=Ernst Wasmuth|location=Berlin|edition=1st}}</ref> and [[Wilhelm von Bode]] in 1895.<ref>{{cite book|last1=von Bode|first1=Wilhelm|title=Teppich-Erzeugung im Orient. Monographien von Sir George Birdwood in London, Geheimrath Dr. Wilhelm Bode in Berlin, C. Purdon Clarke in London, M. Gerspach in Paris, Sidney J. A. Churchill, M. R. A. S. in Teheran, Vincent J. Robinson in London, u.a.|date=1895|publisher=Verlag des K. K. Österreichischen Handels-Museums|location=Wien}}</ref> Since then the Dragon and Phoenix carpet has been referred to in many books on Oriental carpets.
A similar fragment was discovered in [[Fustat]], with dragon and phoenix depicted in combat on a yellow field. The animals in this fragment are depicted in red, and outlined in blue. The minor border shows a variant of the "kufic" borders known from other Seljuq period carpets.
=== Marby rug === Another carpet showing two medallions with two birds besides a tree was found in the Swedish church of Marby in [[Jämtland]] province. The rug was radiocarbon dated to 1300–1420.<ref name="Beselin, 2011"/> More fragments of this type were found in Fostat, today a suburb of the city of Cairo.<ref name="Lamm, 1937">{{cite book|last1=Lamm|first1=C.J.|title=Carpet fragments: The Marby rug and some fragments of carpets found in Egypt (Nationalmuseums skriftserie)|date=1985|publisher=Swedish National Museum|isbn=978-9171002914|edition=1937 reprint}}</ref> The Marby rug is divided into two rectangles, each containing an octagon with a tree and a pair of birds. The tree is mirrored along the horizontal middle axis of the octagon in a way which suggests its image is reflected in water.<ref name="Lamm, 1937"/>
Both the Phoenix and Dragon, and the Marby rug, have additional rows of knots on their backsides. At a distance of every 6 cm, rows of loosely tied knots of red thread are woven in. Another carpet fragment from [[Fustat]] has similar additional knots. It has been suggested that these rows of knots mark the weaver's progress during a given time. On average, the additional knots are repeated every 15 rows in the Dragon and Phoenix rug. At an estimated original width of 1 m, about 3800 knots were woven between two rows of the additional red knots, consistent with the dimensions of the carpet and the amount of knots a single weaver can tie in a carpet during a day.(Beselin 2011, p. 46–49<ref name="Beselin, 2011"/>)
=== Animal carpet at the Metropolitan Museum === The "Dragon and Phoenix" and the "Marby" rugs were the only existing examples of Anatolian animal carpets known until 1988. Since then, seven more carpets of this type have been found. They survived in Tibetan monasteries and were removed by monks fleeing to Nepal during the [[Cultural Revolution|Chinese cultural revolution]]. One of these carpets was acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art<ref name="MET animal carpet Acc.Nr. 1990.61">{{cite web|title=Animal carpet at the Metropolitan Museum of Art|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/453317|accessdate=12 July 2015}}</ref> which parallels a painting by the [[Siena|Sienese]] artist [[Gregorio di Cecco]]: "The Marriage of the Virgin", 1423.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Gallery London|url=http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/probably-by-gregorio-di-cecco-di-luca-the-marriage-of-the-virgin|website=National Gallery London NG 1317|accessdate=12 July 2015}}</ref> It shows large [[confronted animals]], each with a smaller animal inside.
=== Animal carpets from the Vakıflar Museum === The field of an animal carpet in the Vakıflar Museum, [[Istanbul]] (Inv. No. E-1)<ref name="Balpinar, 1988">{{cite book|last1=Balpınar|first1=Belkıs|last2=HIrsch|first2=Udo|title=Carpets of the Vakiflar Museum Istanbul = Teppiche des Vakiflar-Museums Istanbul|date=1988|publisher=U. Hülsey|location=Wesel|isbn=3923185049|pages=190–191}}</ref> is divided into two rectangular compartments by a band similar to its borders. An octagon containing [[confronted animals]] is inscribed into each compartment. The winged animals face a stylized tree. They show a down-turned, snout-like head, to which antler-like extensions are attached, and their body is spotted. Overall, the animals more resemble [[fallow deer]] than birds, which are usually depicted on animal carpets. Deer and fallow deer are already depicted on the borders of the [[Pazyryk carpet]], and are frequently seen on early textiles and other objects in Anatolia and Iran. Below each deer, and above the main animal, is a bird-like quadruped.<ref name="Balpinar, 1988"/>
Another animal carpet with a coarser design compared to the Vakıflar rug is at the [[Mevlana Museum]] in [[Konya]] (Balpınar, 1988, p. 62<ref name="Balpinar, 1988"/>).
=== Animal carpet from the Pergamon Museum === Another carpet in the Pergamon Museum was dated to before 1500 AD. It shows four double-headed quadrupeds within a rectangular field surrounded by an eight-pointed star. The uppermost star is cut off. The stars are framed by smaller octagonal ornaments, two at their sides, one each at the top and bottom of each star. A smaller guardian border separates the field from the main border, which shows stylized leaves adorning S-shaped ornaments. Smaller triangular elements of the design and the outlines of the animals are woven in offset knotting. By its colours, the carpet has been localized to Central Anatolia. On the reverse of the carpet, additional [[Warp and woof|wefts]] can be seen meandering over two [[Warp and woof|warps]] after about every 22 regular wefts. The additional weft changes its colour from yellow to red, roughly at the middle of the carpet. It has been interpreted to show a day's work of two weavers working besides each other. If taken as such, the number of knots woven by each weaver would amount to roughly 2,500 knots per day. (Beselin 2011, p. 50–1<ref name="Beselin, 2011"/>) See: [[knot density]].
=== Batári-Crivelli fragment, Museum of Applied Arts, Budapest === The animal carpet fragment is approximately half the original size. Its field contains two large, 16-pointed star medallions of identical design which both include an eight-pointed star within an octagon. In every second segment of the medallions two birds appear, alternating with two four-legged animals. The field between the medallions is ornamented with smaller rosettes and eight-pointed stars. Each corner contains a [[mosque lamp]] ornament. In the center of the long side an octagonal smaller medallion is inserted. The Batári-Crivelli fragment resembles the "Dragon and Phoenix" and "Marby" rugs in having a yellow ground and two large medallions as the main element of design. [[Chromatography|Chromatographic]] analysis of the dyes revealed yellow from an undefined plant, [[indigo]] blue, [[Rubia tinctorum|madder (Rubia tinctorum)]] red, a blue green derived from indigo, Dyer's weed ([[Reseda luteola]]), and Dyer's sage ([[Salvia fruticosa]]), dark brown and undyed, ivory wool.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Batári|first1=Ferenc|title=Ottoman Turkish carpets|date=1994|publisher=Budapest Museum of Applied Arts|location=Budapest|isbn=978-9630492126|page=46}}</ref> During the 13th International Congress of Turkish Art, held in Budapest on 3 September 2007, the fragment was renamed in honour of Ferenc Batári, the late curator of the carpet and textile department of the museum.
Other animal carpets are at the [[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]] and in private collections.
== Animal carpets in Renaissance painting == {{see also|Oriental carpets in Renaissance painting}} Animal-style carpets begin to appear in Italian paintings in the 14th, and continue to be depicted in Western European paintings throughout the 15th century. They represent the earliest Oriental carpets which were identified in [[Oriental carpets in Renaissance painting|Renaissance painting]]. The comparison of animal-style carpets on Renaissance paintings, for which the painter and the date of origin are often known, allows for the determination of a [[Terminus post quem|"''terminus ante quem''"]] date for existing carpets of similar design. Wilhelm von Bode identified a carpet on [[Domenico di Bartolo]]'s 1440 painting ''The Marriage of the Foundlings'' with marked similarities to the "Dragon and Phoenix" carpet. This marks the beginning of the "ante quem" method, which was subsequently further elaborated by the "Berlin School" of History of Islamic Art. By this method, a variety of existing carpets could be dated by comparison to their painted counterparts.
The illustrated rugs are generally drawn by the early Renaissance painters in a simplified manner, compared to the original carpet designs. The artists may sometimes have painted the animals out of their imagination, but the general appearance of the painted rugs still resembles the originals.<ref name="Yetkin, 1981"/>
A general compositional analysis of the animal-style rugs from Renaissance paintings was first developed by [[Kurt Erdmann]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Erdmann|first1=Kurt|title=Orientalische Tierteppiche auf Bildern des XIV. und XV Jahrhunderts = Oriental animal carpets on paintings of the 14th and 15th century.|journal=Jahrbuch der preussischen Kunstsammlungen|date=1929|issue=5|pages=261–298|jstor=23350357}}</ref> The field of animal carpets is usually divided into rectangular compartments, large or small. Each compartment contains an octagon, which in turn contains animal figures of four types: # "Heraldic" animals, including single- or double-headed eagles; # A pair of birds and a tree; # Single birds or quadrupeds in a geometric frame; # Paired animals within a frame, sometimes depicted in combat.
=== 14th century === At the beginning of the 14th century, carpets with stylized single- or double-headed eagles appear. These are frequently seen in paintings of the [[Italian Renaissance painting|Siena and Florence school]]. During the second half of the 14th century, stylized birds opposing a tree appear in [[Lippo Memmi]]'s ''Virgin Mary and Child'', 1340–50, and in [[Sano di Pietro]]'s ''Marriage of the Virgin'', 1448-52. Yetkin has identified a similar rug in the Vakıflar Halı Museum, Istanbul (Yetkin 1981, plate 17<ref name="Yetkin, 1981">{{cite book|last1=Yetkin|first1=Serare|title=Historical Turkish Carpets|date=1981|publisher=Turkiye is Bankasi Cultural Publications|location=Istanbul|edition=1st}}</ref>). The field of this rug is arranged in the common style, with birds facing a tree, but the birds are crested, and their design is more elaborate. The corners of the composition are filled with animal motifs, perhaps dragons. An animal-style rug with this more developed design appears on a painting by [[William Larkin (painter)|William Larkin]] (Yetkin, 1981, p. 28<ref name="Yetkin, 1981"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mills|first1=John|title=Early animal carpets in Western paintings|journal=Hali|date=1978|volume=1|issue=3|pages=234–43}}</ref>).
A carpet fragment with a single bird with its head turned is now in the collection of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fragment of an animal carpet|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/448133?rpp=30&pg=1&ft=carpet+fragment&pos=18|website=Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=6 September 2015}}</ref> A painted counterpart can be seen in [[Niccolò di Buonaccorso]]'s "Marriage of the Virgin", 1380.
<gallery widths="147px" heights="147px" > File:Fra Bartolomeo Annunziata miracle painting 1252 Annunziata Florence.jpg|One of the first Oriental carpets in a European painting, attributed to the legendary Friar Bartolomeo, ''[[Annunciation]]'', 13th Century, the Church of [[Santissima Annunziata, Florence]].<ref>http://www.museumsinflorence.com/musei/Santissima-Annunziata.html</ref> File:Lippo memi (ambito), madonna del latte, 1340-50 ca.JPG|Lippo Memmi's ''Virgin Mary and Child'' features an "animal carpet" with two opposed birds besides a tree, 1340–50 File:Niccolo di Buonaccorso. Marriage of the Virgin.1380. London NG.jpg|Niccolò di Buonaccorso, ''Marriage of the Virgin'', 1380. [[National Gallery]], London </gallery>
=== 15th – 16th century === By the beginning of the 15th century, the variations of the animal design increase:
Two animal-style carpet fragments from Fustat were dated to the 15th century.<ref name="Lamm, 1937"/> They contain parts of a different version of the tree-and-birds pattern seen in the Marby rug. The field is no longer divided into fields, and the tree-and-paired birds pattern appear in offset rows, covering the field in endless repeat (Yetkin, 1981, p. 29, plates 18,19<ref name="Yetkin, 1981"/>).
A fresco in the [[Palais des Papes]] at Avignon, by [[Matteo di Giovanni]] depicts a carpet with rather indistinct bird figures in front of the Pope's throne. Written sources of the 14th century indicate that [[Pope Benedict XII]] very much liked a carpet with "white swans", which he had set before his throne. A painting by [[Giovanni di Paolo]], 1440, shows an Anatolian animal style rug with birds spread before the pope's throne (Yetkin, 1981, p. 33, ill. 5 and 6<ref name="Yetkin, 1981"/>).
Various examples are known of paintings with single birds in rows without the rectangular field partition. A rug in the [[Konya Archaeological Museum]], dated to the 15th century, represents an original from this group (Yetkin, 1981, p. 31, plate 20<ref name="Yetkin, 1981"/>). A painting by [[Jaume Huguet]] in the [[Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya]] contains a nearly identical rug. Similar rugs can be seen in a painting by Giovanni di Paolo in the [[Doria Pamphilj Gallery]], Rome, and in "Madonna enthroned" by [[Ambrogio Lorenzetti]] (Yetkin, 1981, p. 34, ill. 7 and 8<ref name="Yetkin, 1981"/>). Another animal-type carpet of different design appears in [[Carlo Crivelli]]'s "Annunciation", 1482. The design of this rug consists of stylized animal figures arranged between eight-pointed stars. A paired animal rug can be seen on [[Fra Angelico]]'s [[San Marco Altarpiece]].
The Pergamon Museum's "Phoenix and Dragon" finds its painted counterparts in Domenico di Bartolo's "The Marriage of the Foundlings" (1440) shows a very similar rug, as well as [[Alesso Baldovinetti]]'s "Tale of Saint Vincenzo Ferrerio", and [[Jacopo Bellini]]'s "Annunciation".
The Vakıflar Museum's animal carpet has a painted counterpart in [[William Larkin (painter)|William Larkin]]'s "Portrait of Dorothy Cary, later Viscountess Rochford". The animals shown in the painted rug are very similar to the small bird-like animals in the Vakıflar carpet. As known so far, the carpet depicted in Larkin's portrait is the last of its kind, and the last animal carpet seen in a Western European painting (Balpınar, 1988, p. 62,<ref name="Balpinar, 1988"/> Yetkin, 1981, p. 36<ref name="Yetkin, 1981"/>).
The Batári-Crivelli fragment finds its parallel in two paintings by [[Carlo Crivelli]], the ''Annunciation'' of 1482 in the [[Städel]] museum in Frankfurt and the ''Annunciation, with Saint Emidius'' in the [[National Gallery]] (1486). Both paintings depict a carpet with a sixteen-pointed star motif, with some compartments containing highly stylised animal motifs.
<gallery widths="147px" heights="147px" > File:Sano di Pietro - Marriage of the Virgin - WGA20771.jpg|Sano di Pietro, ''Marriage of the Virgin'', 1448–52, [[Pinacoteca Vaticana]] File:Domenico di Bartolo The Marriage of the Foundlings 1440.jpg|Domenico di Bartolo's ''The Marriage of the Foundlings'' features a large carpet with a Chinese-inspired [[Phoenix (mythology)|phoenix]]-and-[[dragon]] pattern, 1440 File:Crivelli detail of Almsgiving 1486.jpg|Carlo Crivelli, detail of ''Annunciation, with Saint Emidius'', 1486. [[National Gallery]], London File:Carlo Crivelli 037.jpg|Carlo Crivelli, "Annunciation", 1482. Tempera on [[Populus|poplar]]. [[Städel]], Frankfurt am Main, Inv. 841A File:Crivelli_carpet Virgin Mary Annunciate 1482.jpg|Carlo Crivelli ''Annunciation'' (detail), Städel, Frankfurt am Main, 1482 File:Altar sm-1.jpg|Fra Angelico, San Marco Altarpiece, 1438–43 File:Larkin cary.jpg|William Larkin, ''Dorothy Cary, later Viscountess Rochford'', 1614–8, [[Kenwood House]] </gallery>
